Nvidia (NVDA) reports just as its stock has recovered from a late-December dive, Twitter's (TWTR) quarterly numbers may show some signs of growth, Yum Brands (YUM) will report for the first time since spinning off its China operations, and CVS Health[ticker…

Will Bob Iger stay on as chief executive of Walt Disney (DIS)? Maybe, if he has to.When pressed about his succession plans on the Walt Disney's earnings call late Tuesday, Iger said that if prolonging his stay at the House of Mouse was in the best interest of the company, then he was "open to" that, but he also made clear that there was nothing to announce. His current contract expires in June 2018.The comments came on the heels of a Wall Street Journal report Monday in which Disney insiders said they expected Iger to stay on amid an ongoing search for his replacement. Then-COO Thomas Staggs stepped down in 2016; the board reportedly was not certain that he was the right fit for the top spot.For the quarter, Disney logged a surprise year-over-year decline in revenue, with a 3% drop to $14.78 billion, short of estimates for an uptick to $15.26 billion. But adjusted EPS fell a less-than-expected 5% to $1.55, beating views by a nickel.Shares are down fractionally after closing down 0.5% to 109 in the stock market today, ending the session still in buy range after breaking out of a saucer-with-handle base with 106.36 entry at the start of the year.Media networks, the segment that houses ESPN, saw revenue slip 2% to $6.2 billion. Iger reaffirmed bullishness about the premium sports cable network, highlighting deals with new streaming platforms that have produced some "nice gains" in subscriptions. He added that those subscriptions aren't fully counted by Nielsen.He also called out streaming media service BAMTech, of which Disney owns a one-third stake, and said that he expects to launch a direct-to-consumer sports streaming service in calendar year 2017."The quality of that technology has just blown us away," said Iger.Iger announced last August plans to introduce an ESPN-branded over-the-top service, though it would be one that provides "complementary" programming that ESPN has licensed but isn't airing.In Q1, ESPN's subscriptions declined, and the network logged a decrease overall "due to higher programming costs and lower advertising revenue, partially offset by affiliate revenue growth."Despite the success of "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story," the studio arm faced understandably tough comparisons to the prior-year quarter's "The Force Awakens," although "Doctor Strange" and "Moana" box office sales helped to offset a decrease in theatrical distribution revenue.Overall, studio revenue fell 7% to $2.5 billion.Meanwhile., consumer products revenue tumbled 23% from last year's Q1, during which "Star Wars" and "Frozen" merchandise sales provided tough year-over-year comparisons.Disney's theme parks and resorts unit was the only segment to log a year-over-year increase during the quarter, with 6% growth to $4.6 billion.RELATED:What To Expect From Disney Earnings; Will Iger Stay On As CEO?

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), Panera Bread (PNRA), Yum China (YUMC) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) reported earnings after the close. Here are the results and guidance.Estimates: Fourth-quarter earnings per share of 8 cents on revenue of $2.05 billion.Results: Q4 EPS of 17 cents. Revenue was $1.978 billion. Same-store sales were flat.Yum China also named a new COO and other management changes, and announced a $300 million stock buyback.Stock: Yum China edged higher in late trading. Shares had closed down 2.4% to 28.10 in the stock market today. The stock is currently in a cup base.The company was spun off from Yum Brands (YUM), the parent of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, in November. Yum Brands reports results on Thursday.Yum Brands stock finished up 0.3% to 66.51, just above a 66.36 buy point, but in below-average volume.RELATED:Yum Brands Stock Dives Late As Earnings, Sales Miss; China Comps DownYum China Pops In Debut Amid Slowing Economy, Restaurant WoesEstimates: Fourth-quarter EPS down 4% to $1.27, with revenue up 5% to $514.35 billion.Results: EPS plunged 34% to 87 cents, with sales up just 1% to $494.2 million.Outlook: 2017 EPS of $5.60-$6 vs. views for $6.48. Buffalo Wild sees 1%-2% comps growth in 2017.Stock: Buffalo Wild Wings fell 4% in early after-hours action. Shares had fallen 0.9% to settle at 149.80 after briefly moving back above their 200-day line. Buffalo Wild Wings has been up and down for the past year.The chicken-wing chain's fortunes often hinge on big sporting events during the year. However, activist investor Marcato Capital has pressed for more refranchising in the company to ease corporate costs and changes to its board.Buffalo Wild Wings on Monday said that Marcato had submitted a notice to nominate four people to the chain's board at its annual meeting this year.The company said it believed its board "has the skills, qualities and perspectives to effectively address the evolving needs of the Company," but added that it would review the notice.RELATED:Beer, Wings And Fighting Robots Work For Dave & Buster'sEstimates: Fourth-quarter EPS of 33 cents, up from an 18-cent per-share loss a year ago. Revenue is expected to slip 3% to $1.04 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS of 49 cents, revenue up 9% to $1.168 billion.Stock: Pioneer Natural Resources were little changed late. Shares of the oil-and-gas explorer, which is heavy exposed to the lucrative Permian Basin, sank 3.4% to 174.95 in regular trade. Pioneer Natural Resources, undercut the low of its flat base and approaching its 200-day line.Crude futures, which already closed down at a 3-week low, extended losses late after the American Petroleum Institute reported a strong crude inventory build.Estimates: Q4 EPS up 6% to $2.00 on revenue of $727.75 million, up 5%.Results: EPS rose 9% to $2.05. Revenue advanced 5% to $727.1 million. Company-owned comparable sales climbed 3% while franchise comps slid 1.4%. Digital sales now account for 24% of total sales in company-owned stores.Outlook: Panera sees 2017 EPS of $7.45-$7.70 vs. views of $7.67. Panera sees comps growth of 3.5%-4.5%.Stock: Panera shares rose 2% in after-hours action, trading in breakout territory. The stock closed down 0.6% to 214.27. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 218.10.Panera Bread is a fast casual bakery/cafe.

Walt Disney (DIS) discloses first-quarter results after the close Tuesday, and while all the usual components are in play — the studio arm will likely be lauded, ESPN subscriptions will face analyst scrutiny — a new report indicates that CEO Bob Iger may not be able to retire next year, as he originally planned.Disney insiders believe that Iger, whose contract ends in June 2018, will have to stay on to train his successor, according to a Wall Street Journal story, as the media conglomerate remains silent on who might head one of the most well-known entertainment brands in the world.The ascension pipeline has been looking murky since Thomas Staggs stepped down as COO last spring. He reportedly did so amid doubts from the board that he was the right man for the job.During Disney's last earnings call, Iger was mum on the details, except to say that "the process is ongoing, it's robust, and we're all confident that it's going to result in the board choosing not only the right candidate, but the right candidate on a timely basis."Expect a similar question Tuesday.For fiscal Q1, Disney is projected to notch an 8% per-share earnings decline to $1.50 on a 0.1% revenue uptick to $15.26 billion.While "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" was a blockbuster for the studio arm, it faces tough comparisons to 2015's "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." A "Star Wars" movie every year for the next several years means that the Force will likely be strong with Disney's movie segment.But BMO Capital Markets analyst Daniel Salmon a few weeks ago downgraded the stock's rating to underperform, noting that he sees "more negative data points than positive for ESPN" and believes that "consensus Studio estimates embed better performance per film, which is a key risk, in our opinion."Investors appear to have largely recovered from their hand-wringing over ESPN subscriber numbers, first triggered in August 2015, when Iger noted modest losses. The frown lines in the stock have largely been smoothed over, with shares still in buy range after breaking out of a saucer-with-handle base with 106.36 entry at the start of the year.Shares were down 0.75% at 109.47 in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Salmon believes Disney's stock is more likely to test the 90-ish end of its trading range than the 120s, as bullishness about the studio's film slate might already be "overdone." He noted in October that he sees ESPN subscriber losses accelerating, with streaming skinny-bundle subscriptions only partially offsetting those declines.But Piper Jaffray's Stan Meyers raised his price target to 130 from 115 late last month, with an overweight rating, citing the strength of Disney's studio, consumer products and theme parks segments.He said that he expects consumer products to "become the company's most profitable segment" in fiscal 2017, helped by the film slate at Disney, which owns Lucasfilm, Marvel and Pixar.Notably, Hasbro's (HAS) strong earnings, which sent shares up 14% Monday, come on the back of Disney princess and "Frozen" toy sales.

Baidu (BIDU) has hired Qi Lu to be group president and chief operating officer as the search engine giant emphasizes artificial intelligence and self-driving cars.Dr. Lu had previously been Microsoft (MSFT) executive vice president in charge of its applications and services unit. Lu stepped down late last year, citing medical issues from a bicycle accident months earlier. Lu previously ran on Microsoft's search unit and spent 10 years at Yahoo (YHOO) before joining Microsoft in 2009."To achieve our goals, especially in artificial intelligence, which is a key strategic focus for the next decade, we will need to continue attracting the best global talent," Baidu said in a statement.Lu holds more than 40 patents.Baidu is pushing AI to fuel growth, with a special emphasis on self-driving cars. Baidu and Nvidia (NVDA) late last year agreed to collaborate on autonomous vehicles. Baidu will use Nvidia's Drive PX 2 product.Both Baidu and Nvidia have other self-driving alliances, with Nvidia also providing chips to Tesla Motors (TSLA) among others.Baidu this month announced a deal with state-owned Beijing Automotive Group. A BAIC-built self-driving car using Baidu tech will be shown at the Shanghai auto show in April. They plan some testing on Chinese roads this year.RELATED:Nvidia Unveils Artificial-Intelligence Tech For Baidu Self-Driving Cars

Cloud platform vendor VMware (VMW) saw its shares climb to a 17-month high Friday, after the company late Thursday posted Q4 earnings that comfortably beat on the top and bottom lines — boosted by a product that won't come out until at least the summer.VMware, majority owned by Dell, in October announced a partnership with Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services, the No. 1 provider of cloud services infrastructure. VMware On AWS is slated for release later this year, but the anticipation of its release is already helping, says VMware executives and analysts alike.The AWS partnership "assures customers we will remain leaders" in the shift to the public cloud, VMware COO Sanjay Poonen told IBD in a phone interview Friday.In the public cloud, companies and enterprises are putting most of their operations into data centers not on-site but in the data centers of cloud services providers led by, in order, AWS, Microsoft's (MSFT) Azure, Alphabet's (GOOGL) and IBM (IBM).IBD'S TAKE: VMware was trading in above average volume Friday following its earnings, but it didn't make IBD's Stocks on the Move, the place to go to find top stocks being bought, or sold, in especially heavy volume.As the No. 1 maker of virtualization software, which lets servers run multiple operating systems and thus increases flexibility and lowers costs, VMware is a longtime leader in private cloud computing. But its focus has quickly shifted to helping companies with their hybrid — public and private — cloud computing environments.VMware also has a hybrid cloud partnership with IBM. "We had nothing and now we have major partnerships with Nos. 1 and 4 (in public cloud services), and likely will be doing more with Nos. 2 and 3 in due course," Poonen said.VMware does have smaller partnerships with Microsoft and Google, companies that at times can also be rivals. But in the era of "co-opetition" it's seldom a "case of black-and-white" in looking at rivals and potential rivals, says the COO, who joined VMware in 2013. "Almost all the (big tech companies) are potential partners," he said.Microsoft is a good example of a frenemy relationship, he says. VMware has security products and more for Microsoft's Office 365 software as a service. "We have a very good partnership," Poonen saidThe world is moving to the public cloud, he said, and points out VMware has been building its portfolio of public cloud-focused products. But he says bigger companies, VMware's main customers, might not complete the transition for another decade, assuming they do move all operations to the public cloud.Analysts are bullish on the AWS partnership."Consistent with our recent VAR(value added reseller) survey, the AWS partnership has prompted customers to view VMware in a more strategic light when it comes to public/hybrid cloud capabilities, which according to management has already been an accelerant to VMware's business even though the VMware Cloud on AWS service does not go live until the summer," Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair, said in his research report, maintaining an outperform rating on the stock."The strategic alliance with AWS has been a major catalyst in terms of customer perception, and ... it is already paying dividends in the form of a strengthening near-term business," Ader wrote.At least five investment banks hiked their price targets on VMware stock following the earnings report, which included a slight beat in Q1 sales guidance and slight miss on EPS guidance. And the company announced a $1.2 billion share buyback program, added to its ongoing $500 million buyback program.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Ben McFadden maintained a sector weight, or neutral, rating on VMware stock, but he said the share buybacks were a big plus. He also wrote, in a research note, that "improved results have brought optimism back into the story." But he also said "we look for a sign of inflection in results or successful data points around the AWS partnership before becoming more positive on shares."VMware stock ended Friday trading up 3.5% to 87.16 on the stock market today, and shares have doubled in the past 52 weeks. It sports a solid IBD Relative Strength Rating, meaning the stock has been among the top 15% in performance over the past year, with an emphasis on the most recent six months.VMware also is changing its fiscal year, which in 2016 coincided with the calendar year. Its new year's, fiscal 2018, ends Feb. 2, 2018. Its guidance is for the year that ends on that date. In May, besides reporting its fiscal Q1 results, it will separately report results for what it calls the current "stub" period of Jan. 1-Feb. 4.RELATED:Roundup Of Late-Thursday EarningsCould Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms

Starbucks (SBUX) shares haven't been anything to write home about over the last year or so but have still managed to carve out a base, and fiscal first-quarter earnings late Thursday could provide enough of a jolt to send the stock into buy range.Wall Street analysts are expecting 13% profit growth — the slowest in five years — to 52 cents a share on 9% sales growth to $5.85 billion. The relatively weak profit gain comes as traffic at brick-and-mortar retailers, which are often adjacent to Starbucks locations, is losing more ground to e-commerce, pushing the company to expand its upscale offerings."Our question is whether the company can overcome the natural erosion of traffic across retail (discussed in length at the Dec. 7 analyst day) or whether pricing efforts around premiumization are possibly too aggressive," wrote Buckingham Research Group analyst John Zolidis on Tuesday.While same-store sales managed to match forecasts last quarter, that metric in the U.S. has in recent quarters gotten a lukewarm reception on the Street.Wedbush's Nick Setyan said he expects "sustained comp momentum" in the Americas segment, while RBC Capital Markets' David Palmer said comps have been improving through the quarter. Zolidis, Setyan and Palmer are all estimating 4% in same-store sales for Q1. In Q4, Starbucks had global comp growth of 4%, and 5% in the Americas.At an investor day last month, COO Kevin Johnson said cold drinks, lunch offerings and continued digital and mobile efforts are three core comp drivers going forward.Shares ended trading up 0.4% at 58.70 on the stock market today, closing in on a 59.64 entry in a saucer-with-handle base. Investors should note a few technical points on this technical analysis. If you look at Starbucks' chart as a base going back to Oct. 30, then the midpoint of the handle is fractionally lower than the midpoint of the consolidation. But, using the 52-week high set in April, the handle — and 59.64 buy point  — are valid.McDonald's (MCD), which has tried to regain some coffee drinkers from Starbucks, was up 0.6% to 121.79, staying above its 50-day and 200-day lines. McDonald's dipped Monday after reporting Q4 results that topped views but indicated momentum from its menu revamp was fading.Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) finished up 0.5% to 52.01.IBD'S TAKE: Buying and selling stocks ahead of a company's earnings announcement can be dicey, but options plays on Swing Trader offer a way to at least cap the risk while still participating in the potential upside.Howard Schultz, who is handing over the CEO reins to Johnson in April, will be focusing on the rollout of the more premium Starbucks Roastery and Starbucks Reserve locations amid what he calls as "over-retailed" American consumer environment. Schultz envisions 20 to 30 "really grand" Roastery hot spots and a big fleet of smaller premium Reserve locations.The company's current five-year plan includes 10% revenue growth, 15%-20% profit growth, mid-single-digit annual same-store sales gains and 12,000 more locations globally.Aggressive growth plans in China mean that we can expect to see twice as many Starbucks in the country — around 5,000 — by 2021, which the company expects will nearly triple the segment's revenue and operating income.But some initiatives have proved short-lived. The Seattle Times reported earlier in the month that Starbucks planned to close its "Evenings" offerings on Jan. 10 amid the buildout of the new premium locations. The program attempted to turn nearly 440 U.S. coffee shops into more after-work-friendly destinations with wine, beer and small plates. (The new premium locations will offer spirits.)RELATED:Starbucks CEO Says U.S. 'Over-Retailed,' Plans To Add 12,000 StoresWhat To Expect From Starbucks' CEO Shuffle — Shaky Or Seamless?Starbucks' Schultz To Step Down As CEO; No Other Leadership Change Seen

Shares of rail giant CSX (CSX) soared Thursday after a report said Canadian Pacific (CP) CEO E. Hunter Harrison will step down and team with an activist investor to try to put the industry veteran in a top management position at CSX.Harrison, who helped lead Canadian Pacific's failed Norfolk Southern (NSC) takeover attempt last year, will leave five months earlier than planned, with the Wall Street Journal reporting that he will partner with Paul Hilal, who left William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management to launch his own fund, Mantle Ridge, last year.Harrison is also cutting ties to Canadian Pacific, which agreed to a limited waiver of non-compete obligations, according to a company statement late Wednesday. COO Keith Creel will take on the CEO role.CSX, which reported mixed Q4 results Tuesday, jumped 23.4% to 45.51 on the stock market today.CSX's board is open to talks with Mantle Ridge, but is happy with its current growth strategy, the Wall Street Journal reported.Norfolk Southern shares climbed 4%. Union Pacific (UNP), which beat earnings forecasts Thursday, added 2.4%, while Kansas City Southern (KSU), which reports Friday, reversed to end down 0.5%. Canadian Pacific climbed 3.5%.Creel will become Canadian Pacific's president and CEO effective Jan. 31, following Harrison's decision to retire.The company said Wednesday that "Harrison had approached the board to discuss his retirement from CP and potential related modifications to his employment arrangements that would allow him to pursue opportunities involving other Class 1 Railroads."In return for the limited non-compete waiver, Harrison agreed to end all roles with Canadian Pacific, forfeit benefits and stock awards totaling 118 million Canadian dollars, and no longer carry out a previously agreed-upon consulting role.Last summer, the company said Creel would take over July 1, 2017. He had already had stints serving as interim CEO during periods when Harrison had health issues.In April, the company abandoned its effort to buy Norfolk Southern for $30 billion amid broad opposition from industry and lawmakers. At the time, Harrison doubted that Canadian Pacific would pursue other rail rivals.The accelerated CEO handoff comes days before President-elect Donald Trump, who has vowed to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, is sworn in.

Stock futures drifted lower Monday ahead of a holiday-shortened week as U.K. Prime Minister Teresa May on Tuesday plans to call for Britain to exit the European Union's single market. Meanwhile, Netflix (NFLX) is among a slew of key earnings in the coming days. Netflix along with the other FANG+ stocks, Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) are all in or near buy range.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 fell about 0.1%-0.5% vs. fair value in early Tuesday trading.U.S. financial markets were closed Monday in observance of the Martin Luther King, Jr. holiday. The Nasdaq closed last week up 0.5% on Friday, hitting an all-time high. The Dow industrials edged lower while the S&P 500 climbed 0.2%, both trading near record levels.PM May plans to announce Tuesday that Britain will leave the EU's single market, emphasizing control over borders, immigration and other sovereignty. It will be the clearest signal yet that May will seek a "hard Brexit." Business groups had hoped that May would support a "soft Brexit," agreeing to EU demands on the free movement of people in exchange for continued access to the single market.IBD'S TAKE: Investors should focus on companies with superior earnings growth. Here are 14 stocks, including Morgan Stanley, set to report 50% earnings growth or more for the latest quarter.The British pound rallied as of early Tuesday morning to above $1.21 after falling below $1.20 intraday Monday amid early reports of May's intentions. The FTSE 100 dipped 0.15% on Monday, ending a 14-day win streak, including 10 straight sessions hitting record highs. The benchmark British index has many global multinationals that often benefit from a weaker pound that flatters their dollar-based revenues.Meanwhile, in the U.S., the earnings season will kick into high gear. UnitedHealth Group (UNH), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Chinese for-profit school operator New Oriental Education (EDU) report earnings before Tuesday's opening bell. United Continental (UAL) and rail operator CSX (CSX) will release Q4 results late Tuesday.On Wednesday, Netflix will report fourth-quarter earnings. As always, investors will pay close attention to subscriber growth and Netflix's subscriber outlook.Netflix on Friday surged 3.5% to 133.70 in heavy volume, moving back above its 129.40 buy point after undercutting that entry on Thursday. Meanwhile, Apple and Alphabet are also in buy range, while Amazon and Facebook have rallied to about 3%-4% from breakouts.In other news, Noble Energy (NBL) agreed Monday to pay $2.7 billion in cash-and-stock for Clayton Williams Energy (CWEI), the latest notable Permian Basin shale deal.General Motors (GM) this week will announce plans to invest $1 billion in U.S. plans, creating more than 1,000 jobs, according to multiple reports Monday. That follows threats from President-elect Donald Trump to impose border taxes on GM cars made in Mexico.Baidu (BIDU) hired ex-Microsoft exec Qi Lu to be the search engine's COO.Gold futures advanced 1.3%, continuing a strong rally in 2017. U.S. crude futures edged above $52 a barrel.Japan's Nikkei 225 index fell 1.5% intraday, hitting the lowest levels since early December. The Shanghai composite slid 0.4%, on track for the worst close since October.RELATED:Apple, Google, Netflix Are In Buy Range; Amazon, Facebook Near BreakoutsTrump Inauguration, Netflix, GE, IBM, Davos Forum Lead Investing Action PlanGM To Join Ford, Rivals In Repackaging U.S. Investment Plans For TrumpNoble Pays $2.7 Billion For Clayton Williams In Permian Basin DealThe Big Picture: Nasdaq Up For Week, S&P 500 Nearly Flat; 9 Stocks For Possible BuysBaidu Hires Ex-Microsoft Exec As COO In Artificial Intelligence Push

Loading the player... Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. With the Dow Jones industrial average still trying to claw its way to the 20,000 mark, markets will look to earnings reports from Dow components General Electric (GE), Goldman Sachs (GS) and IBM (IBM) as well as Inauguration Day…

Nvidia (NVDA), Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Square (SQ), Autodesk (ADSK) and Tronc (TRNC) were among the notable companies that saw insider stock trades as 2016 was about to end.Insider transactions don't typically have a major impact on a stock or indicate major pending news. Sales can be triggered automatically at certain dates or prices under trading plans set up in advance, and sometimes are used to cover taxes on the executive's shares. Rapid liquidation of all or most of an insider's holdings, however, can affect a stock.Director Tench Coxe, who is also a managing director at venture capital firm Sutter Hill Ventures, sold 50,000 shares at 116.70 a piece for about $5.8 million, according to a filing from Thursday.But the trade date was Tuesday, when the stock hit a record high above 117. On Wednesday, short seller Citron Research made bearish comments on Nvidia, sending shares down 6.9% to 109.25.For the week, shares of the graphics chipmaker fell 2.7%.RELATED:Down Comes Nvidia And The Tech ETFs That Rode It To Stellar GainsCFO Luca Maestri sold 2,300 shares this week. Shares of the tech giant have lagged the Dow for much of the year on concerns about waning iPhone demand. But they have had better luck at year's end, nearing a buy point from a cup base begun in October.Apple shares dipped 0.6% this week, consolidating near their 118.79 entry.RELATED:Top 10 Trends To Watch For 2017: From Trump To Apple iPhone 8AI, Virtual Assistants, Augmented Reality Vie For Next Big Thing At CESCOO Sheryl Sandberg sold 109,000 shares of the social-media giant this week for about $12.8 million, continuing a steady stream of exercised sell options. Chief Product Officer Christopher Cox sold 15,600 shares.While Twitter (TWTR) subscriber growth failed to keep investors happy this year, Facebook's rose through much of 2016. But the stock got dinged last month after Facebook said it expected ad placement and ad revenue to decelerate in the quarters to come.Shares fell 1.9% for the week and closed at their lowest level since July. Facebook's relative strength line, which tracks the stock's performance vs. the S&P 500, is at an 11-month low.RELATED:Facebook Brings Pac-Man, Space Invaders To Messenger PlatformCEO Lisa Su sold 87,683 shares of the graphics chipmaker for a value of around $1 million, and CFO Devinder Kumar sold 36,356 shares, with both selling to meet tax-withholding obligations.Advanced Micro Devices, which competes with Nvidia in the market for chips used for video games and other fields, has extended a partnership with Mentor Graphics (MENT) and is rumored to have struck a licensing deal with Intel (INTC).AMD shares lost 2.1% this week, pulling back as Nvidia reversed. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base in November.RELATED:AMD Stock Hits Six-Year High On Intel Rumors, Ahead Of Zen PreviewNvidia Flashes Key Sell Signal Amid Citron Tweet, Possible Climax RunCEO Jack Dorsey sold 381,500 shares of the electronic payments company this week. Square has faced concerns this year about slowing growth in its customers, as well as concerns about Dorsey's dual role as CEO of Square and Twitter. But the stock has rebounded since the summer as it attracts larger merchants and broadened its services to businesses. The company's mobile wallet partnership with Apple has also helped shares.Shares fell 3% from a week ago, continuing their formation of a handle in a cup base.RELATED:Square Upgraded, 'Estimates Could Prove Conservative'CEO Carl Bass disclosed this week the sale of 52,419 company shares that took place last week. The design software maker in November gave a weak fourth-quarter forecast, but Canaccord Genuity upgraded the stock on the prospects of its transition to the cloud.Shares finished with a 2.6% decline for the week.RELATED:A Beginner's Guide To The CloudDirector Michael Ferro and his Merrick Venture Management hedge fund last Friday purchased 2.5 million shares of the media company, formerly Tribune Publishing, for $37.5 million from investment firm HG Vora.The trade was disclosed this week. Ferro now owns 24.8% of Tronc, which publishes the Los Angeles Times, the Chicago Tribune and other newspapers. Ferro took a $44 million stake in Tribune earlier this year.As the Chicago Tribune noted, on that Friday Tronc's board also ended a shareholder-rights agreement that limited ownership to 20%, a move intended to ward off Gannett's (GCI) attempts to buy the company.Tronc's shares crashed in October as financial support for Gannett to acquire the company fell apart. However, shares of Tronc, Gannett, the New York Times (NYT), McClatchy (MNI) and others have rebounded on an explosion of new subscriptions amid Donald Trump's election.Tronc, which stands for "Tribune online content," earlier this year released a video introducing employees to the rebranded company that was widely panned as quasi-cerebral media speak.Shares eased 0.8% this week, but found support at their 200-day line.Editor's note: This article has been updated to clarify the reasons for the stock sales by AMD CEO Lisa Su and AMD CFO Devinder Kumar.

Walt Disney (DIS), GoPro (GPRO), McDonald's (MCD), Jack in the Box (JACK), Shake Shack (SHAK) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) saw analyst action Friday.RBC Capital Markets upgraded the media titan to outperform from sector perform and upped its price target to 130 from 101."We think the tide is turning for sentiment around DIS, driven by improving affiliate trends, portfolio optionality and rotation out of (Time Warner)," wrote analyst Steven Cahall late Thursday.Disney shares closed up 1.5% at 108.98 on the stock market today, still within buy range after a Wednesday breakout.  Time Warner (TWX) shares dipped 0.4% to 94.75.The action-camera maker received a downgrade to underperform from Longbow Research.Shares dropped 3% to 9.07 Friday.GoPro CEO Nick Woodman told IBD late Thursday that the company is working on a consumer 360-degree video camera, but that mass interest in spherical capture and VR is still early.IBD's TAKE: For more news and stock analysis from CES 2017 in Vegas this week, check out our full coverage of the major tech event.UBS cut the Golden Arches' rating to neutral, while Buckingham Research downgraded Shake Shack to neutral from buy. Shake Shack said late Thursday that CFO Jeff Uttz will retire in March, and named Zach Koff as its new COO.Meanwhile, Telsey Advisory increased its price target on Jack in the Box to 125 from 120. It has an outperform rating on the stock.McDonald's shares rose 0.9% to 120.76, Shake Shack tumbled 7.25% to 36.59, and Jack in the Box fell 1.7% to 106.28.RBC Capital Markets cut the drug stock's price target to 598 from 626 with an outperform rating.On Thursday, a federal judge ruled that Regeneron and partner Sanofi (SNY) infringed on a patent held by Amgen (AMGN).Regeneron shares tumbled 5.8% to 358.68.

The Fed raised rates and signaled hikes are coming at the same time President-elect Trump met with the heads of Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Tesla Motors (TSLA) and more. Oil prices rallied on a weekend deal by non-OPEC countries to curb output in solidarity with the cartel. And "Rogue One," the latest Star Wars film for Walt Disney (DIS), got off to strong start.The Dow rose modestly while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged lower, but all held near record highs. The Fed raised rates, pushing the 10-year rate hit a 2-year high while the 2-year yield was the most since 2009. Bank stocks, which have surged in recent weeks, were flat to slightly lower for the week. Energy groups rallied with oil prices. Nvidia (NVDA) hit a new high while several chip stocks entered buy range.The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the second time since the financial crisis, as expected. Policymakers also signaled that they aim to hike rates three times in 2017, up from two moves in September. The economy is improving and financial markets seem to be taking the Fed hike and outlok in stride, making policymakers more likely to carry out their tightening plans this time. As Pres.-elect Trump plans big tax cuts and infrastructure spending, Fed chief Janet Yellen said the U.S. economy doesn't need a fiscal boost.RELATED:Fed Sees 3 More Hikes In 2017; 'Fiscal Boost Not Needed,' Yellen SaysNFIB's small business optimism index rose to their highest level in two years, and post-election responses were much higher. Home builder confidence hit an 11-year high, even with mortgage rates soaring and housing starts plunging. Philly Fed-area factories also see much brighter days ahead. That follows the IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index, which showed consumer sentiment at a 10-year high in December. However, despite all this optimism, retail sales rose just 0.1% in November and 0.2% excluding autos. Consumer inflation rose to a two-year high.RELATED:Factory Growth Jumps, Builder Sentiment SoarsNovember Retail Sales Rose Just 0.1%: No Trump Holiday Bump?President-elect Donald Trump aimed to build bridges to Silicon Valley and other technology companies in a high-tech summit in New York. Most of the tech industry's leadership backed Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. Topics discussed innovation, China, immigration and high-tech jobs, and improving the economy with digital technologies. Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos later said it was a "productive" meeting. Chief executives from Apple, Cisco Systems (CSCO), IBM (IBM), Intel (INTC), Microsoft (MSFT), Oracle (ORCL), and Tesla Motors also attended the meeting, as well as Google-parent Alphabet CEO Larry Page and Chairman Eric Schmidt. Also on hand was Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg and the CEO of privately-held Palantir. In another development, Trump tapped Tesla's Elon Musk and Uber CEO Travis Kalanick to join a group of advisors.RELATED:Trump, Silicon Valley Shake Hands; Amazon's Bezos Hails 'Productive' MeetingPresident-elect Donald Trump tweeted that the F-35 program's costs were "out of control." The fifth-generation fighter has come under attack by Sen. John McCain and others for years of cost overruns and delays, but Lockheed Martin (LMT) defended the program saying costs have come down by 70%. Lockheed shares fell for the week, with fellow defense contractors Northrop Grumman (NOC,) Raytheon (RTN) and General Dynamics (GD) also losing ground. In the prior week, Trump tweeted that he might cancel Boeing (BA)-made Air Force One replacement planes, citing the cost. Trump has also taken on Ford (F) and United Technologies (UTX) division Carrier division for plans to shift production to Mexico.RELATED:Lockheed's F-35 Isn't Stealthy Enough To Avoid Trump's Latest AttackTrump Seeks To Cancel Air Force One Order, Targets Boeing ProfitOil prices spiked higher on Monday after Russia and several big non-OPEC producers agreed to curb output along with OPEC, while Saudi Arabia hinted that it would cut its production by even more. But U.S. crude rose just 0.8% to $51.90 for the week. OPEC says the "NOPEC" deal will help rebalance the oil market in the second half of 2017, but it sees output from non-OPEC states overall increasing next year by more than previously expected. Analysts question how long the deal will last before producers start cheating as Russia is already seen wobbling. The Federal Reserve's rate increase sent the dollar higher, weighing on crude prices. The Energy Information Administration said U.S. stockpiles fell by more than expected, but crude production climbed. The number of U.S. oil rigs continued to rise.RELATED:Oil Sinks As Fed Hikes Rates, Oversupply Fears Linger'NOPEC' Deal Could Send Oil To $60 By January, But Can It Be Enforced?Fiscal Q4 earnings rose 45% as sales climbed 23% to $1.61 billion, both topping forecasts. It was Adobe Systems'ADBE sixth straight quarter of revenue growth of at least 20%. Creative cloud revenue climbed 33% to $866 million. The digital media and marketing software firm sees Q1 EPS above consensus and revenue slightly below.Adobe shares sank 1.5% on Friday.RELATED:Adobe Systems Beats Sales, Earnings Targets For Q4Adjusted earnings fell 3% to 61 cents, just above views, while non-GAAP revenue climbed 1% to $9.07 billion, just missing. Oracle is trying to shift to an on-demand, cloud-based model: Cloud revenues reached $1.1 billion. Cloud software as a service (SaaS) and platform as a service (PaaS) non-GAAP revenues rose 87% to $912 million.Oracle shares fell 4.3% Friday.RELATED:Oracle Tops On Earnings, Misses On RevenueLucasfilm's first live-action "Star Wars" spinoff movie generated $29 million in midnight Thursday screenings. "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" was expected to take in up to $150 million domestically in its opening weekend, perhaps $300 million worldwide. That should be good news for Walt Disney (DIS). So far, "Rogue One" has garnered generally solid, even rave, reviews from the critics. Piper Jaffray sees Disney's global box office total hitting $7 billion in 2016 and $6.5 billion in 2017. The conglomerate's studio successes may, for the time being, take the spotlight off its cord-cutting woes at ESPN.Viacom (VIAB) and CBS (CBS) won't be walking down the aisle together: Shari Redstone, vice chairwoman to both companies, axed National Amusements' earlier proposal encouraging a merger of the sluggish cable operator with the top broadcast network, a decade after their split. Redstone and her father Sumner control both companies via National Amusements. The Redstones wrote that they were "very impressed" with interim Viacom CEO Bob Bakish, who was then named permanent chief exec of the Comedy Central and MTV parent. Verizon Communications (VZ) denied interest in swooping in to buy CBS. Viacom shares fell sharply, though they pared losses somewhat Friday on news that Sumner Redstone would give up his vote on the board in early 2017, raising hopes that the company would be open to a takeover. CBS fell initially but rose to fresh two-year highs by Friday.Yahoo (YHOO) shares tumbled on fears that Verizon will scrap its planned takeover of the ailing portal's core operations. Yahoo late Wednesday disclosed yet another massive hack attack. Charter Communications (CHTR) rose on buzz that Verizon might bid for the cable operator instead.RELATED:Viacom Pulls Plug On Possible CBS MergerVerizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo Down

President-elect Donald Trump says he's on his way making America great again with the help of Silicon Valley and other technology companies.Trump told tech industry leaders at a meeting in New York that his goal is "to help you folks do well." "We want you to keep going with the incredible innovation," he added, according to video of the start of the meeting.Trump's meeting with Silicon Valley leaders contended for the news spotlight with the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates for the first time this year, with three more moves possibly coming in 2017.The meeting's general topic was on jobs and how the economy can be improved with digital technologies, according to reports.Amazon.com (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos, who also owns The Washington Post, had positive, carefully crafted comments after the meeting."I found today's meeting with the President-elect, his transition team, and tech leaders to be very productive," Bezos told Yahoo Finance in a statement. "I shared the view that the administration should make innovation one of its key pillars, which would create a huge number of jobs across the whole country."Chief executives from Apple (AAPL), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Microsoft (MSFT) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) also attended the meeting, as well as Google-parent Alphabet's (GOOGL) CEO Larry Page and Chairman Eric Schmidt. Aside from Apple's Tim Cook, Amazon's Bezos, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, and presumably Cisco's Charles Robbins and Tesla's Elon Musk, CEOs from Intel (INTC), Oracle (ORCL) and IBM (IBM) were on hand. So was Facebook (FB)COO Sheryl Sandberg.IBD'S TAKE: The largest tech stocks, in general, have not joined as much in the stock market rally post-Trump triumph, with sectors such as oil and banks seeing a bigger boost, though Apple and FANG (Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google) stocks have done better of late. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.In other developments, Trump tapped Musk and Uber CEO Travis Kalanick to join a group of corporate advisors that will advise on job creation and the economy. The group of business leaders is led by Stephen Schwarzman, the chief executive of Blackstone (BX). It also includes General Motors (GM) CEO Mary Barra and Walt Disney's (DIS) chief Bob Iger.Google, meanwhile, has stepped up hiring of lobbyists with Republican ties, says a Reuters report.Google had several insiders at the Obama administration, including Megan Smith, former U.S. chief technology officer. Smith acted as liaison between tech companies in Silicon Valley and the White House.It's not clear whether Trump transition advisor Peter Thiel will have a role in the administration. Thiel, a PayPal (PYPL)co-founder and venture capitalist — and Trump's biggest Silicon Valley champion during the campaign — helped organize Wednesday's tech industry summit.Trump had clashed with the tech industry over immigration reform and data encryption policies during the campaign. Trump has pressured Apple to move some iPhone manufacturing to the U.S. Trump has called Amazon a monopoly that benefits from unfair tax benefits.Trump has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, with tax rates falling from 35% to 10%. Tech companies such as Apple and Google have the most overseas cash.Most of the tech industry's leadership backed Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. Apple shares closed unchanged on the stock market today, as the major averages retreated following the Fed's rate hike decision. Amazon stock slid 0.7%. Shares of most of the other big techs with execs at the Trump summit rose or fell less than 1%.RELATED:China Seen Hitting GM On Price Fixing Amid Trump RhetoricApple, Microsoft, Cisco Eye Trump Overseas Cash Tax Plan

Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook, Facebook (FB)  COO Sheryl Sandberg and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) co-founder and CEO Larry Page and Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt are among tech industry leaders expected to attend a summit with President-elect Donald Trump on Wednesday, Bloomber and online news site Recode reported Sunday, where U.S. economic growth as well as China, taxes and immigration policies could be on the agenda.Most tech industry leaders who attend will fly east from Silicon Valley. The meeting is planned at the Trump Tower in Manhattan.Trump transition advisor Peter Thiel, a PayPal (PYPL) co-founder and now a noted venture capitalist, has also reached out to Microsoft (MSFT) CEO Satya Nadella, and the chief executives of Cisco Systems (CSCO), IBM (IBM), Intel (INTC) and Oracle (ORCL), according to reports. Thiel was by-far Trump's biggest high-level Silicon Valley tech backer, even speaking in a prime spot at the Republican National Convention.Apple's Cook, Oracle co-CEO Safra Catz and Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins have confirmed they're going, says a Bloomberg report. Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk also will attend, the Wall Street Journal reported Monday, though Recode on Sunday said Musk was iffy.IBD'S TAKE: Apple and most of the FANG stocks are showing weak relative strength vs. the broader market. True market leaders show rising RS lines. To find stocks with RS lines hitting new highs, take a free Marketsmith trial.Netflix (NFLX) CEO Reed Hastings, Twitter (TWTR) CEO Jack Dorsey and Uber CEO Travis Kalanick will not be attending and have other plans, said the Recode report.Recode on Sunday said it wasn't clear if Amazon.com (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos would attend, but Yahoo reported Monday that Bezos would attend.During the Presidential campaign, Trump called Amazon a monopoly and said it benefited from unfair tax advantages. Trump also has feuded with the Washington Post, which is owned individually by Bezos.Worries that Trump trade policies or future comments over Taiwan could raise tensions with China's government remain a concern of Apple, because of iPhone sales in China.Google, meanwhile, apparently won't have the same kind of access to top officials at the Trump administration as it did during the Obama administration.Trump has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, with tax rates falling from 35% to 10%. The top five overseas cash holders are Apple, Microsoft, Google, Cisco and Oracle.During the Presidential campaign, Trump stated his opposition to the H-1B specialty-occupation non-immigrant visas — a key tool of U.S. tech companies looking outside the U.S. to fill key skilled tech jobs that they say are otherwise tough to fill.The largest tech stocks, in general, had not joined as much in the stock market rally post-Trump triumph, with sectors such as oil and banks seeing a bigger boost, though the big techs have done better of late. But Apple stock fell 0.57% in the stock market today, while Facebook and Amazon fell 1.6% and 1.1%, respectively.Apple stock found some support at its 50-day moving average, a key support line, while Facebook and Amazon were facing tests at their 200-day and 10-day lines, respectively.Netflix stock was flat at 122.83. It has a buy point of 129.40 out of a cup-with-handle base. Google stock fell a small fraction to 807.90, still above its 50-day line after retaking that support level on Friday for the first time since Nov. 10.RELATED: Apple, Microsoft, Cisco Eye Trump Overseas Cash Tax Plan

As Goldman Sachs Group's (GS) Gary Cohn prepares to decamp for a Trump administration job in Washington, there's no shortage of bankers lined up to replace him.Cohn, the firm's president and chief operating officer, has accepted the job as President-elect Donald Trump's chief economic policy advisor, CNBC reported Monday. Jake Siewert, a Goldman Sachs spokesman, declined to comment, while Cohn, 56, didn't immediately respond to a phone message.Jason Miller, a spokesman for the Trump transition team, said "the president-elect has not yet made an announcement on that front, but stay tuned."Among potential replacements for Cohn, who has been in line to succeed Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein, are seven executives on the bank's management committee: Harvey Schwartz, David Solomon, Stephen Scherr, Marty Chavez, Eric Lane, John Waldron and Pablo Salame, people familiar with the process have said.While Schwartz and Solomon are considered front-runners, it's not clear how the roles may be divided. Blankfein, 62, could choose two executives to split Cohn's duties, naming each as co-president and co-COO, as he did in 2006 in assigning the titles to Cohn and Jon Winkelried. He also may choose a different configuration, designating one as president and the other as COO, or name someone else to what's considered the steppingstone to the CEO's chair.For those bypassed for the clear No. 2 job, Blankfein has a number of options to appease them. The CEO could name one or more of them as vice chairman, an honorific and a nod to those executives deemed instrumental to the firm's success. Vice Chairmen Michael Sherwood and Mark Schwartz, considered close associates of Blankfein's, have announced their plans to retire this year. Blankfein could also sweeten the deal for an executive getting a smaller role by awarding that person a larger pay package.Here's the background of the executives thought to be in the running for Cohn's job, listed in order of likelihood, the people familiar with the company's politics have said:Schwartz, 52, was named chief financial officer in January 2013 after 15 years at the company. In one of the most visible roles at the Wall Street firm, Schwartz has slashed almost $1.5 billion in expenses as the bank copes with a revenue slump brought on by increased regulation and stubbornly low interest rates.Schwartz, whose pay package for 2016 totaled $27.7 million, joined Goldman Sachs in 1997 as a vice president in the currency and commodities-trading unit, which was then managed by Blankfein and Cohn. Schwartz, a 6-foot-4 graduate of Rutgers University, later joined the investment-banking division as co-head of a new financing group in 2004.In February 2008, two weeks before Bear Stearns collapsed, Schwartz became one of four co-heads of global sales and trading. After being named a member of the risk committee two months later, Schwartz was forced to wrestle with decisions about how to protect Goldman Sachs and allocate capital as the crisis led the firm to sell assets and hold more cash and other liquid securities.Blankfein, Cohn and Schwartz have resisted investors' calls in recent years to pull back on fixed-income trading as revenue from the unit slumped, instead urging patience even as competitors including Morgan Stanley scale back.Solomon, 54, succeeded Winkelried as co-head of investment banking in July 2006 as one of Blankfein's first appointments. Solomon joined Goldman Sachs in 1999 from Bear Stearns as co-head of the high-yield debt and leveraged-finance division before becoming co-head of equity capital markets in 2002.While the investment-banking co-heads share responsibilities, Solomon is the primary leader of the day-to-day business, with a focus on efficiency and profit. His name has long been on a short list of potential successors to Blankfein or Cohn, and was part of the group known as Goldman Sachs's "brain trust" during the financial crisis, according to Andrew Ross Sorkin's 2009 book "Too Big To Fail."Solomon was on the phone with Blankfein, Cohn, Winkelried and then-CFO David Viniar as the group engineered a deal to sell Warren Buffett $5 billion worth of stock in the form of preferred shares with a 10% dividend as well as warrants that allowed him to buy additional shares, according to Sorkin's book. The deal came the day after Goldman Sachs was named a bank holding company in September 2008 as investors worried whether it would need additional capital to stay afloat.Chavez, 52, was named chief information officer in December 2013 after being appointed to the management committee earlier that year. The Albuquerque, New Mexico, native holds a doctorate in medicine from Stanford University and bachelor's and master's degrees from Harvard University, where he took a course on Literature of the Weimar Republic.Chavez joined Goldman Sachs in 1993, working in the currency and commodities division that also produced Cohn, Blankfein and Schwartz. He left the firm in 2000 and founded Kiodex Inc., which offers risk-management services to energy companies. Chavez rejoined the bank in 2005, was named a partner the next year and has overseen Goldman Sachs's principal strategic investments group.A former director of the International Swaps & Derivatives Association, Chavez has said he's nostalgic for the boisterousness of the trading floors of the past as traders are now quiet because "everyone's instant messaging." Still, he said he's excited about the opportunities technology brings to banking."The possibility of software eating the world — you can be nervous about it or you can be excited about it," Chavez said at a philanthropic event in May. "It's a choice. I'm choosing to be excited about that transformation."Scherr, 52, has been chief strategy officer since June 2014 and took over as CEO of Goldman Sachs's bank in May. The firm has been building out its banking operations under his leadership, completing the purchase of General Electric Co.'s online bank and debuting Marcus by Goldman Sachs, an online-loan service that targets consumers with credit-card debt.Scherr joined Goldman Sachs in 1993, working in the fixed-income trading division from 1996 to 1999 before moving to investment banking. A partner since 2002, he was appointed to the management committee in January 2012.He took over Goldman Sachs's underwriting business in 2008, leading it to the top spot in debt underwriting for the first time in its history. The group produced a record $4.03 billion in 2013, his last year at the helm, and also ranked first in global equity offerings. Before running the financing group, Scherr spent two years as COO of the investment-banking division.Salame, 50, was named co-head of the securities unit in 2008 after joining in 1996 as part of the emerging-markets currency-trading group. He was named partner in 2000 and assigned to help lead the global emerging-markets debt group. Two years later, he moved to London where he later became co-manager of global credit, mortgages, emerging markets trading and equity derivatives before taking on his current role. He returned to New York in 2011.He leads the partnership committee, a panel that helps define the experience of being a partner.A native of Ecuador, Salame won his doubles tennis event in the inaugural Finance Cup in 2015, helping the U.S. team top the European squad. He's also a member of the board of trustees at Brown University.Lane, 42, was named co-head of the investment-management division in December 2011 after working in the unit for 10 years. The business oversees private equity and hedge funds and handles money for wealthy individuals, and Blankfein has made expanding the unit a priority.Lane, who former Goldman Sachs executives have said is close to Cohn, joined the firm in 1996 and was named partner in 2002. He was appointed to the management committee in 2012 and, like Solomon, donated to Republican Jeb Bush's presidential campaign last year.The investment-management division, with Tim O'Neill as its other co-head, has seen total assets managed climb more than $500 billion to $1.35 trillion since Lane took the post, according to company filings. Lane and O'Neill, who've made nine acquisitions in their time running the business, have said they want to increase the unit's revenue by more than 10% a year.Waldron, 47, was named co-head of the investment-banking division in December 2014, joining Richard Gnodde and Solomon. He was named to the management committee with the promotion.During Waldron's first year co-heading the unit, Goldman Sachs topped the league tables, advising on more than $1.41 trillion of deals — a record for the firm. He joined Goldman Sachs in 2000 after following Solomon from Bear Stearns, was appointed partner in 2002 and became co-head of leveraged finance in 2005.He briefly moved to London in 2007 to become co-head of the European financial sponsors group, building a team that advises European private equity firms.

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Starbucks (SBUX) holds an investor day less than a week after Howard Schultz said he will step down as CEO in April 2017. Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) will report earnings as fellow discounters Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Big Lots (BIG) approach…

Starbucks (SBUX) head Howard Schultz will step down as chief executive officer next April, the coffee shop giant said Thursday.Schultz will "focus on retail innovation and accelerating growth of Starbucks ultrapremium retail formats," according to the statement on Starbucks' press site.Current COO Kevin Johnson will be the new chief executive officer. He took the new COO post two years ago, with some observers at the time speculating he was the heir apparent.On a conference call later, Johnson said no other leadership changes are planned.Schultz, currently chairman, will be executive chairman after stepping down as CEO.Shares fell 3.7% in late trading. Starbucks closed up 0.9% to 58.51 on the stock market today.Presumably more details of the succession will be provided at Starbucks' investor day next Wednesday.Schultz  joined the coffee company in 1982, then bought the retail unit in 1986, renaming its Starbucks. Schultz was a long-time CEO of Starbucks, but stepped down from 2000-2008. His return coincided with a revival in Starbucks' growth.

The quartet of internet stocks called FANG were showing signs of struggle Wednesday, a key reason why the Nasdaq lost just over 1%.The FANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google-owner Alphabet (GOOGL), were all down Wednesday afternoon, as was Apple (AAPL).Facebook fell back below its 200-day trading average, retreating nearly 2% to 118.51 in the stock market today.Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, along with Chief Technology Officer Michael Todd Schroepfer and COO Cheryl Sandberg, recently sold large blocks of Facebook stock. Insider sales are sometimes viewed as a negative.IBD'S TAKE: Apple and the FANG internet giants have not joined in the postelection stock rally, while bank, drug, defense and basic-material stocks have gained. A first step for CAN SLIM investors is to understand the difference between technical and fundamental analysis, both of which are critical to successful stock-picking.Alphabet lost 1.7% to 775.76, heading back toward its 200-day trading average after turning back from its 50-day average. Google recently announced the Pixel-branded phones, along with Google Home, a voice-activated smart speaker that challenges Amazon's Echo virtual digital assistant.Amazon, which is trading below its 50-day moving average, was down 1.5% to 750.86.Analysts say Amazon is entering a new investment cycle, evident by its third-quarter earnings report that missed estimates due to its larger-than-expected investments in various Amazon businesses. Amazon is reportedly in talks to broadcast live sporting events, which could pose a threat to Netflix and others in the streaming-video field.Netflix stock fell 0.4% to 117.04. Netflix announced it would let users download much of its content for viewing later offline, a feature that Amazon already offers and that users had requested for a long time. Netflix stock is down 9% since hitting a one-year high of 129.30 on Oct. 24. It's forming a cup-with-handle base, with a possible buy point of 129.40.Apple stock fell 0.8% to 110.60. Shares are trading below the key 50-day moving average, but are also forming a flat base, with a possible buy point of 118.79. RELATED:Amazon Spreads Its Tentacles Far Beyond 'World's Biggest Bookstore'

As Walt Disney (DIS) Chief Executive Officer Bob Iger's scheduled retirement date looms closer, the entertainment giant's search for his replacement remains low-profile, a departure from the open process it previously employed.It's been seven months since heir apparent Tom Staggs' abrupt departure left Iger without a clear-cut successor. The top executive recruiting firms say they haven't been hired by Disney, and Iger hasn't moved members of his executive team into newer or more prominent roles to audition them for the top spot. The company has said only that there is a process in place that the board is following, which will include evaluating internal and external candidates.While there's still time to conduct a search before Iger's contract ends in June 2018, the quiet nature of the current succession planning stands in sharp contrast to the widely watched, five-year bake-off from which Staggs emerged as the leading contender for the job. That's fueling speculation that the board could request that Iger, 65, stay on longer than his scheduled retirement date, something it has already asked of him twice before."I don't think anyone — employee, investor or director — would be hesitant in granting him a new contract," said Anthony DiClemente, an analyst at Nomura Securities in New York. "That could happen quickly and easily. Why hasn't it happened already? That's a fair question."Iger said on a May conference call with investors that he didn't have any plans to stick around past the current date."The board is very actively engaged in a succession process, as it has been actually for some time," he said. "It believes that it has ample time to identify a successor under timing circumstances that will be just fine for the company."A spokeswoman for Disney declined to comment further. Disney board members on the governance and nominating committee, including former Starbucks (SBUX) CEO Orin Smith, Twitter (TWTR) CEO Jack Dorsey, Facebook (FB) Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg and former Clorox (CLX) Chairman Robert Matschullat, didn't respond or declined to comment.Typically it takes a big public company six to seven months to complete a search once the board begins to contact and interview prospective candidates, though additional time is required before that, said Peter Crist, chairman of Crist Kolder Associates, a boutique search firm outside Chicago. "We do lots of mapping projects with the company that take months" about the qualities it wants and needs in a new CEO, Crist said.At Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) executive recruiter Spencer Stuart began consulting with directors about what the company needed in a new leader and who they should consider about a year before Doug McMillon was named the retailer's CEO in November 2013, according to people familiar with the situation who asked not to be identified because they aren't authorized to talk publicly. The board narrowed its search to two internal candidates, McMillon and former head of U.S. operations Bill Simon, about six months before making its final decision.At Procter & Gamble (PG), directors first started talking about replacing then-CEO Bob MacDonald in July 2012 and then asked A.G. Lafley to return as CEO and chairman in May 2013. Lafley, who'd already served as CEO at P&G from 2000 until 2009, immediately reorganized the company into four businesses, each headed by a president who was considered a contender for the CEO post. One of the four, David Taylor, was named global president of home care and subsequently also took charge of P&G's beauty business.In July 2015, Lafley and P&G's other directors named Taylor the consumer giant's new CEO, concluding the two-year process.Iger himself was promoted in 2005 after a six-month search by the board. The executive, who had led Disney's TV operations and international business and had served as president for five years, was evaluated against external candidates with help from Heidrick & Struggles, directors said at the time. He got the top job only after a high-profile campaign by some shareholders to oust then-CEO Michael Eisner. Former directors in a long-running feud with the company still criticized Iger's selection as hasty, but the board said it had been thorough and careful.Until this year, it looked as if Disney's choice for Iger's successor would be more orderly, with a seasoned executive waiting in the wings in the COO position. Staggs had risen to the No. 2 spot at the company after a five-year period in which he and another senior manager, Jay Rasulo, competed with each other to become Iger's successor. The two even switched jobs to give Staggs more experience operating a business and Rasulo exposure to the executive suite. Rasulo, then serving as chief financial officer, left the company last year after Staggs' promotion to COO.Staggs' exit, after failing to gain the full backing of Iger and the board, left no other internal candidate with both operational experience and a corporate role.Of the six CEOs since Disney's founding in 1923, only Eisner came from the outside. Eisner, who served from 1984 to 2005, joined the company from Paramount Pictures, where he was president.While the board contemplates who will lead the company after June 2018, Iger remains active in planning how to shape Disney's future. In recent weeks, he considered buying Twitter, but decided to pass, partly because of price and partly because of concern about bullying on the social-media site, people familiar with the matter said last month.At an October event in Boston, Iger said it wasn't enough for the company to own key brands like ABC, ESPN and Pixar. Disney needs to have a direct connection to consumers through mobile devices, he said."What we're thinking about a lot is what role does technology have in distributing from us to the consumer?" he said. "How must we invest in that?"In its search for Iger's replacement, Disney's board should be casting a wide net, looking for candidates inside and outside the company, particularly ones with high-tech chops, said Paul Winum, a senior partner at the management consulting firm RHR International and co-author of "Inside CEO Succession.""The landscape is changing so rapidly, technology is opening up new distribution platforms, overseas markets will be  huge opportunities," he said. "The leadership skills have changed dramatically just in the last two years."When a CEO succession plan unravels, as it did at Disney, the company usually starts thinking about the next, younger generation of executives inside, giving them bigger and different kinds of experience to prepare them for the top job, said Joseph L. Bower, a Harvard Business School professor who has studied succession planning. Disney hasn't made any major changes recently to suggest it's grooming anyone internally, however."Disney isn't in trouble and currently has a strong CEO in place," Bower said. "But you don't want someone to come in at the last minute to take over."

Earnings season always carries with it the triumphs and disappointments of companies, often in dramatic fashion. Two companies on Thursday were cheered on by investors and analysts. Icon (ICLR) announced its earnings before the open and jumped 8% to close at 84.73. That put the stock well above a 79.71 buy point and cleared its all-time high of 84.14 from…

Banks retreated Thursday, testing buy points as Treasury yields fell ahead of earnings from Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) out Friday.Treasury yields were down Thursday after a weaker-than-expected trade report out of China sent investors toward government bonds and other safe assets. Investors have bid financials in recent weeks on the prospect of Federal Reserve rate hikes and the recent rise of long-term yields around the world. JPMorgan fell 0.6% to 67.74 on the stock market today after dropping as low as 66.82, just above the 50-day line. The stock is still in range from a buy point of 65.08, cleared in early August.JPMorgan is expected to report a 17% drop in third-quarter earnings but revenue is seen rising 2% to $23.988 billion when it announces quarterly results Friday.Citigroup shares dipped 0.5% to 48.47 after sinking intraday to 47.54, below a recent 48.24 buy point. Analysts see Citi's Q3 EPS falling 15% on Friday to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344 billion. Wells Fargo shares slid 1.3% to 44.75 well below its 50-day and 200-day lines. The bank has its own issues after a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau review found employees may have opened more than 2 million accounts and credit cards without consumers' permission. Late Wednesday, Wells said CEO John Stumpf stepped down, effective immediately, replaced by President and COO Tim Sloan.Bank of America (BAC) is slated to report results Monday, Goldman Sachs (GS) Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) on Wednesday. BofA shares fell 1.25%, continuing a recent slide after peeking into buy range on Monday. Goldman lost 1.1% and Morgan Stanley 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: U.K.'s Brexit, bad loans at Italian banks and legal troubles from Germany's Deutsche Bank have opened the European market to U.S. banks. Regional banks, more directly dependent of lending than global Wall Street banks, were also under pressure Thursday.Comerica (CMA) shares fell 1.4% to 47.91, still in buy range, with a 46.40 buy point, out of a cup with handle base but falling toward its 50-day line.SunTrust Banks (STI) shares tumbled 2.1% to 44.76 falling toward its 50-day line but still in buy range, above its buy point of 44.42, after consolidating out of a flat base.Regions Financial (RF) stock fell 2.8% to 9.95, finding support at its 50-day line and off session lows of 9.78, but below its buy point of 10.10.RELATED:Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) will report earnings, while investors should keep a close eye on Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen and shares of off-price retailer Ross Stores (ROST). Stocks To Watch The retail sector has been…

Wells Fargo (WFC) CEO John Stumpf will retire from that position and as the bank's chairman, effective immediately, and will be replaced by President and COO Tim Sloan, the bank announced late Wednesday.Lead Director Stephen Sanger will take over as non-executive chairman. Independent Director Elizabeth Duke will serve as vice chair. Sloan was also named to the board.The news comes after Stumpf, who reportedly will not receive a severance payment, faced intense criticism from lawmakers and others following the bank's cross-selling scandal, in which authorities said Wells' sales staff created up to 2 million unauthorized consumer accounts in an attempt to hit sales goals."While I have been deeply committed and focused on managing the company through this period, I have decided it is best for the company that I step aside," Stumpf said in a statement."John Stumpf has dedicated his professional life to banking, successfully leading Wells Fargo through the financial crisis and the largest merger in banking history, and helping to create one of the strongest and most well-known financial services companies in the world," Sanger said in that statement. "However, he believes new leadership at this time is appropriate to guide Wells Fargo through its current challenges and take the company forward."Shares rallied 2% in late trading in the stock market today, after closing down 0.3% in the regular session.The company reports third-quarter earnings on Friday. Investors will likely be focused on any details from the bank on how it will move forward following the scandal.IBD'S TAKE: While U.S. banking giants face tighter restrictions from regulators, their stronger capital positions have helped them take market share from European rivals, who have yet to fully recover from the financial crisis.RELATED:What To Expect From JPMorgan, Citigroup, Wells Fargo Earnings Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

With JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) set to report third-quarter earnings on Friday, the landscape for the big banks has enough in common with what we saw in Q2.In other words, the Fed still opted not to raise interest rates, hurting the banks' net interest margins. The state of the U.S. consumer remained generally solid. And the global "economic uncertainty?" That was still there too."During the third quarter, banks faced another challenging operating environment, with uncertainty and volatility arising after the Brexit vote and lackluster global economic growth continued," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Brian Kleinhanzl said in a research note.The only good news some analysts see is no bad news."Unfortunately, the positive might come in just not having any negatives," Edward Jones analyst Shannon Stemm said.But Citigroup last month cited better trading in Q3 but weaker-than-anticipated investment banking, while JPMorgan remained upbeat on the economy and the state of the consumer.Other factors will be likely to dominate the financial world's attention. Many observers will likely be cued into any commentary surrounding Wells Fargo's cross-selling scandal — in which authorities said the bank's employees created as many as 2 million unauthorized consumer accounts to hit sales targets.The scandal has cost John Stumpf his job as CEO and chairman. The bank said late Wednesday COO Tim Sloan is taking over as CEO and Stephen Sanger is taking over as chair.The Wall Street Journal reported that the bank outlined plans to rebound from the scandal during a conference call on Monday. Details from those plans could be presented on Friday.The scandal over the bank's cross-selling, a point of pride for management only a few years ago, led to some intense questioning from Congress about the bank's culture and executives' knowledge of the sales practices. The financial impact during Q3, however, was limited.Wall Street expects Wells Fargo's earnings per share to fall 4% to $1.01. Revenue is seen rising 1.5% to $22.2 billion."The investment community's going to be looking for some specifics from the management team on what they're going to do to adjust sales practices, and what's that going to look like from a cost standpoint?" Stemm said."And then I think there will be follow-ons to some of the other banks, too – 'What do your sales practices look like? What are you doing to monitor both risky behavior?' What does that look like for future compliance costs?"Beyond cross-selling, KBW expects Wells' net interest margins to be constrained, even after the bank grew loans considerably in quarters past.JPMorgan, another bank KBW said was dependent on loan growth after activity rose rapidly in recent quarters, is expected to report EPS down 17% to $1.39.The bank's equity markets could be a bright spot, KBW said. Revenue is expected to climb 2% to $23.988 billion.Citigroup's EPS, meanwhile, is expected to fall 15% to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344.Citigroup in June also acquired Costco's (COST) U.S. co-brand credit-card portfolio from American Express (AXP). Citi and Costco announced their co-branded credit-card deal last March."(Q3) will be the first full quarter with Costco in the numbers and management has already indicated that the performance within the Costco portfolio is exceeding management's expectations," Kleinhanzl wrote. "If Citi can show material growth in receivables from the Costco portfolio then we would expect shares of Citigroup to do well at earnings."KBW also said Citigroup may have gotten more of a bump from fixed income, currencies and commodities trading. But the bank has said that investment banking during the quarter was "lighter than estimated."JPMorgan dipped 0.3% in the stock market today, while Citigroup lost 0.6% and Wells Fargo eased 0.3%. Bank of America (BAC) fell 0.5%. Morgan Stanley (MS) fell 0.8%, while Goldman Sachs (GS) added 0.15%.IBD'S TAKE: While U.S. banking giants face tighter restrictions from regulators, their stronger capital positions have helped them take market share from European rivals, who have yet to fully recover from the financial crisis.

Bank stocks have rallied in recent weeks as the Fed has shown more openness to raising interest rates. Other factors could extend their gains, Morgan Stanley notes.That uptrend for the banks "could continue if oil prices edge higher, inflation picks up, Yellen raises rates, corporates re-engage," Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck wrote in a research note. "Risks include a divided government post-election, weak C&I growth, and political backlash."Other risks for the banks include commercial lending, which KBW expects to weaken after the U.K.'s vote in June to leave the European Union caused businesses to put plans on hold, which in turn meant less borrowing.Bank of America reports Monday, Goldman reports next Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley reports on Wednesday.IBD's money center banking industry group, where most of the major banks are, was ranked 131st out of 197 groups on Tuesday. It has been in the bottom half of the table for many months.RELATED:U.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Those plans were announced in December.COO Sheryl Sandberg also sold 109,000 shares this week, continuing a string of regular sales.Even as other social-media platforms like Snapchat compete for the attention of young adults, Cowen & Co. this week said "Facebook is still king" among the 18-24 age bracket.Facebook rose 0.6% this week to 128.99, back above a 128.43 buy point.Intel CEO Brian Krzanich sold 67,508 shares this week.The chipmaker's rivalry with Nvidia appears set to intensify as the companies make a push into self-driving automobiles, data centers and augmented reality, as IBD reported this week.Intel climbed 0.9% for the week, ending the week at its best close in more than 15 years.CFO Colette Kress sold 37,804 company shares this week, while director Tench Coxe disclosed the sale of 85,551 shares.Along with self-driving cars, data centers and augmented reality, Nvidia could also be developing processors for Apple devices.Nvidia declined 2.4% this week.Director Raymond Dittamore disclosed the sale of 18,000 company shares.
